Preface
This is my note during the lonely winter break of 2018 in my dorm North Apartment, Amherst, UMass.
During this season, I read Analysis by Terence Tao to prepare for graduate classes Math 697AM Math
Application and Modeling, and Math 697U Stochastic Processes that I will take in Spring 2019. The book
was based on Math 131AH taught at UCLA by Tao himself (course website). SPOILER ALERT: Taos
Analysis is a superb book.
In the rst four chapters, we will build our basic number systems including the natural numbers, inte-
gers, rationals, and real numbers respectively. As we will see, everything about the number systems that we
cherish are built from the ground up starting from 5 axioms of Peano to construct the natural numbers.
Induction is a powerful tool to prove many properties about the natural numbers. This is understand-
able because the natural numbers itself are dened recursively (if n N, then n + + N). Fundamental
operations are also dened recursively. Additions are recursive incrementation. Multiplication is recursive
addition, and exponentiation is recursive multiplication. Fancier operations like subtraction, division and
negation are built later when we have more generalized number system like integers and the rational numbers.
Properties about operations like associativity and commutativity are also proven. The integers are built
from the Cartesian product of the natural numbers, using equivalence classes. Equivalence classes are also
the way that we will build the rationals and real numbers later on.
For each new number system, we will dene the equivalence relation that cut the set into equivalence
classes. We then dene the usual operations and prove properties about them. For appropriate number sys-
tems, these properties are understood systematically through axioms of rings or elds. We will also briey
show that equivalence class is indeed equivalent in the light of operations. Tao calls this substitution axiom:
if x = x
0
, then x y = x
0
y where is some binary operation like addition. We also show the embedding of
the previous number system inside this current system through group homomorphism. Lastly, we deal with
problems relating to ordering and trichotomy. Properties about partial order and total order will be proven.
Trichotomy is related to the connex property of total order. For a simple case of integers, trichotomy states
that a number a Z is either positive, negative or 0.

Chapter 1
Natural Numbers
1.1 Peanos Axioms
This is an axiomatic treatment of the natural numbers. We will construct the natural numbers that we
know and love from scratch, based on a minimal and powerful set of axioms. First to remind the readers,
the natural numbers that we know are
0, 1, 2, ...
To dene this type of numbers, we will need two things: an initial starting point (0) and an increment
operator (++). By incrementing, we mean increasing a number by 1 so 1 = 0 + +, 2 = 1 + +, .... For now,
we can think of ++ as an arbitrary symbol that when applied to a natural number would produce another
natural number.
1, 2, 3, ... are of course just convenient notation. 1 is the increment of 0. 2 is the the increment of
1 or the increment of the increment of 0 and so on. Everything we discuss here still hold if we use a
dierent notations like Roman numerals i.e. I, II, III, ...
Now we will dene two foundational axioms
Axiom 1 (Initial Value). 0 is a natural number.
Axiom 2 (Recursive increment operator). If n is a natural number, then n + + is also a natural number.
However, these two axioms are not sucient. We might have a weird natural number system that loops
back like 0, 1, 2, 3, 2, 4, .... In fact, in computer system, overows will cause the 2s complement represen-
tation to loop back like that. In mathematics, we do not allow this behavior. So we will introduce two
additional axioms to avoid repetition in our number system.
Axiom 3 (Bounded at one end). 0 has no predecessor i.e. there does not exist natural number n such that
0 = n + +.
Axiom 4 (Unique Predecessor). If n and m are two dierent natural numbers, then n + + and m + + are
dierent. Equivalently, if n + + and m + + are the same, then n and m must be the same.
In other words, axiom 4 does not allow this type of situation.

Axiom 3 basically re-arms axiom 1 that 0 is the initial starting point. In the natural number system,
there is no number that comes before 0. From this axiom, we know that 0 is unique. Axiom 4 basically
provides a mechanism that we can use to tell if two given natural numbers are equal to each other.
Example 1: Uniqueness of 0
0 is not equal to 2.
Proof. 2 = 1 + +, but 0 does not have a predecessor. Thus, 2 and 0 must be dierent. This argument can
be easily extended to say that 0 is dierent from 1, 3, 4, ... and so on.
We will soon see that axiom 3 in conjunction with axiom 4 will avoid any repetition in our natural number
system sequence.
Example 2: Uniqueness of any natural number
8 is not equal to 4.

By the unique predecessor axiom 4, we know that 7 = 3 because 4 = 7 + + = 3 + +. Similarly, we know
that 6 = 2, 5 = 1 and 4 = 0. The last statement violates example 1, so we know that 4 can not be repeated.
This essentially says proves that 8 := 7 + + is dierent from 4.

S(n) = n + +. And of course, a function should map a unique x to a unique y. Axiom 4 asserts that S(n)
is injective.

Axiom 5 (Induction). Dene a predicate as a Boolean-valued function f : X {true, f alse} for some set
X. A unary predicate that takes in only one single value (instead of a vector for example) is called property
P . The axiom states that if
P (0) is true and
for every natural number n, P (n) is true implies that P (n + +) is true
then P is true for every natural number.
Note that Figure 1.4 can be eliminated by setting P (n) = n is 0 or n has a predecessor i.e. for every
natural numbers n 6= 0 there exists m N such that n = m + +.
We can prevent Figure 1.5 by setting p(n) = n is 0 or there is a path (in a graphical sense) from n to
0. Obviously, if there is a path from n to 0, then n + + can follows the edge from n + + to n and will nd a
path back to 0. By induction axiom 5, there must be a path from n to 0 for every natural number n. This
means that the second chain must be connected to the rst chain at some point.

1.2. ADDITION 11
Axiom 1 (starting point): 0 N.
Axiom 2 (increment): If n N, then n + + = S(n) N.
Axiom 3 (bounded): 0 has no predecessor i.e. there does not exist m N such that m + + = 0.
Axiom 4 (unique predecessor): S(n) is injective. m = n if and only if m + + = n + +.
Axiom 5 (Induction) For unary predicate (property) P , if P (0) is true and P (n) = P (n + +), then
P (n) is true for all n N .
Axiom 4 denes what it means to say two natural numbers are equal. Before proceeding, we will lay down
a standard denition of equality that would apply to all number sets including natural numbers, integers,
rationals and real numbers.
Denition 1.1.1 (Equality). Equality relation P (x, y) is a binary predicate between two objects x and y
satises three properties:
Reexive: x = x i.e. P (x, x) is true.
Symmetric: If x = y then y = x i.e. P (x, y) = P (y, x).
Transitive: If x = y and y = z, then x = z i.e. (P (x, y) P (y, z)) = P (x, z)
Finally, for the case of natural numbers, we also assume that if x = y and x N then y N.
We can verify that the equality denition of natural numbers in axiom 4 satises three properties above.

We will prove some algebraic properties of addition.
Property 1 (Additive group closure). Sum of two natural numbers are again a natural number.
Proof. With m, n N, we will prove that m + n N by induction axiom 5 on n. For the base case n = 0,
we know by the denition of addition that n + 0 = n N.
Now, assume that the statement is proven for n. We will demonstrate that it also holds for n + +. By
recursive denition, m + (n + +) := (m + n) + + Because by the inductive hypothesis (m + n) = k is a
natural number, k + + is also a natural number by increment axiom 2.
From denition 1.2.2, however, it is not clear that addition is commutative.
n + m = m + n
We will now prove a series of remarks by induction leading to the proof that addition is commutative.
Property 2 (Additive group identity). 0 + m = m
Proof. Note that denition 1.2.2 states that m+0 := m and we have not proven addition to be commutative.
Thus, 0 + m are not necessarily the same as m + 0. Note that the very denition of the natural number m

1.3. MULTIPLICATION 17
1.3 Multiplication
We now move on to multiplication. Similar to addition, multiplication can be dened recursively, but now
in terms of addition instead of incrementation
Denition 1.3.1 (Multiplication). Multiplication has a starting point
n 0 := 0
and is dened recursively in terms of addition
n (m + +) := (n m) + n
with m, n N.
Similar to addition, we will some algebraic properties of multiplication.
Property 5 (Multiplicative closure). If m, n N, then n m N.
Proof. We will induct on m. For the base case m = 1, we have
n 1 := n N
Now, assume the claim is proven for m, we will show that it is also true for m + +.
n (m + +) := (n m) + n
By induction hypothesis, (n m) is a natural number, and we assume n to be natural. And by the additive
closure, we know that sum of two natural numbers are a natural number. Thus, (n m) + n is natural, and
the claim is proven.
Property 6 (Multiplicative identity). n 1 = 1 n = n
We can easily verify from the denition that n 1 = n (0 + +) := n 0 + n = n, so we only need to
show 1 n = n. First, we will show that

1 0 := 0
Now, assume the claim is proven for n, we will show that it is also true for n + +. That is
1 (n + +) = n + +
The left hand side is equal to
1 (n + +) := (1 n) + 1
By the induction hypothesis, we know that (1 n) = n. And we also already show that n + 1 = n + +.
Therefore, the left hand side is equal to the right hand side. Induction is done.

Property 8 (Distributivity). (b + c) a = b a + c a
Proof. We will induct on a. For the base case a = 0, we know that

= b a + c a + (b + c)
Addition is associative so we can move terms around
= (b a + b) + (c a + c) := b (a + +) + c (a + +)
The left-hand side is now equal to the right-hand side, and our induction is complete.
Property 9 (Multiplication is associative). a (b c) = (a b) c
Proof. We will induct on c. For the base case c = 1, we know by the multiplicative identity that
a (b 1) = a b = (a b) 1
Now, we assume the claim holds for c and extends it to c + +. That is we want to show that
a (b (c + +)) = (a b) (c + +)
The left hand side is equal to
a (b (c + +)) := a (b c + b)
Using the distributive law, we have
= a (b c) + a b
By the induction hypothesis, we have
= (a b) c + (a b) := (a b) (c + +)
The left-hand side is now equal to the right-hand side, and our induction is complete.

1.6 Aside: Strong and backward induction
26 CHAPTER 1. NATURAL NUMBERS
1.6.1 Strong induction
Axiom 5 establishes the principle of weak induction. For a property p, if p(0) (p(n) = p(n + +)), then
p(n) is true n N ( means and in logic).
Now we move to another kind of induction: strong induction. The claim is that if you assume p(0), p(1), ..., p(n
1) are all true, and are able to deduce that p(n) is also true, then p(n) is true n N. Obviously, this in-
duction is stronger than our usual induction as it allows us to assume that p(0) up to p(n 1) true. In
weak induction, we merely assume p(n 1) is true. Also, note that we do not need to prove the base case.
This is because p(0) is vacuously true given (p(0) p(1)... p(n 1)) = p(n)). Note that a vacuous truth
is a statement that asserts that all members of the empty set have a certain property. This statement is
automatically true. In other words, properties that can be said about members of an empty set (empty set
has no member!) are assumed to be true for those non-existent members.
Theorem 2 (Strong induction). Let p be a property of the natural numbers. For an arbitrary n N, assume
p(m) is true for all natural m < n. If we can deduce that p(n) is also true, then we can conclude that p(n)
is true for all natural number n.
Proof. Strong induction turns out to be just regular induction in disguise. Specically, we can dene a
new property Q(n) as the property that p(m) is true for all natural m < n. In other words, Q(n) is the
intersection p(0) p(1)... p(n 1). We need to prove Q(n) is true for all n N and this will automatically
imply that p(n) is true for all n N. We demonstrate this by induction.
First, we need to prove that Q(0) is true. In other words, p(m) is true for all natural numbers m < 0.
This is vacuously true because the set of all natural numbers less than 0 is the empty set . Every property
that is attributed to is assumed to be true. Now for the inductive step, we prove that Q(n) = Q(n + 1).
This is when our hypothesis for strong induction comes in. For strong induction, we assume that we are
able to prove (p(0) p(1)... p(n 1) = p(n)). This also means that Q(n) = p(n). And because
Q(n + 1) := (p(0) p(1)... p(n 1)) p(n) := Q(n) p(n), this shows that Q(n) = Q(n + 1). Were
done by weak induction, and we conclude that Q(n) is true for all natural number n. This also means that
p(n) is true for all natural n.
Of course, we do not need to start from 0. We can pick a new starting point m
0
N

that p(m) = p(n) for m

starting from m

0

2.2 Formal dierence
In hindsight knowledge, we know that the integer set is nothing but a set of natural numbers plus some
negative integers, whatever negative might mean. We would inevitably have to introduce the idea of
subtraction. But now, we will follow Taos approach in his book Analysis. We would introduce a meaning-
less symbol , and dene the integers as all number of the form a b, where a, b are our known natural
numbers.
Essentially, an integer is a pair of two natural numbers. This denition is rigorous because we know what
natural numbers are. We postulate the existence of natural numbers, and we also dene rigorously the idea
of 2-tuple. So essentially, the integer set is the Cartesian product of the natural numbers N N. We also
need a mechanism to tell when two integers are equal to each other as well.

a b

Denition 2.2.2 (Equal integers). With a, b, c, d N, we say that two integers are equal to each other
a b = c d
if and only if
a + d = b + c.
We know a + c N, and b + d N. We also know how to tell when two natural numbers are equal to
each other. Thus, we should also know when two integers are equal to each other.
We should check that this denition of equality satisfy all three properties of equivalence relation. Reexive
and symmetric are trivial. We will show that under 2.2.2 transitivity holds. That is
((a b) = (c d) (c d) = (e f )) = (a b) = (e f)

a + d + c + f = b + c + d + e

Theorem 5. Integers under addition form Abelian group
Proof. We already show (Z, +) is a group so we only need to show that x + y = y + x for x, y Z. This is

2.4 Multiplication
Denition 2.4.1 (Integer multiplication). (a b) (c d) := (ac + bd) (ad + bc)
Like natural multiplication, integer multiplication has many properties that we would characterize them as
a monoid.
Denition 2.4.2 (Monoid). (S, ) is a monoid if it
1. has an identity element.
2. is associative
3. is closed under
That is a monoid is a group without the inverse property.
Theorem 6. Integers under multiplication is a monoid.
Proof. First, we will identify the identity element as
{(a + +) a : a N}

and
b a + c (a + +) = b a + c a + c

(b a + b + c a) + c = (b a + c a + c) + b
This is true.
Next, we will prove that multiplication is associative. Let x = a b, y = c d, z = e f , we aim
to prove that

2.5 Commutative Ring
We introduce the concept of a ring and show that the integers form a commutative ring.
Denition 2.5.1 (Ring). A set R with two binary operations + and is a ring if satisfying
1. R is an Abelian group under +.
2. R is a monoid under .
3. is distributive over +. i.e.
a (b + c) = a b + a c
A ring is commutative if is commutative.
e will need to show distributivity and multiplicative commutativity of the integers.
Property 16 (Distributivity). For x, y, z Z, we have
x (y + z) = x y + x z
Proof. Let x = a b, y = c d, z = e f, we have

:= (a(c + e) + b(d + f)) (a(d + f) + b(c + e)
Using the algebraic properties of the naturals including the distributive law to rearrange terms, we have
= ((ac + bd) + (ae + bf)) ((ad + bc) + (af + be))
= x y + x z

2.6 Natural embedding in the integers
We will now show that the natural numbers are, in some sense, a subset of the integers. We dene a concept
in group theory: homomorphism
Denition 2.6.1 (Group homomorphism). Let (G, ) and (H, ) be two groups. If there exists a function
f : G H such that
36 CHAPTER 2. INTEGERS
f(a b) = f(a) f (b), for all a, b G
Then, f is called a homomorphism between G and H.

Figure 2.2: Group homomorphism
Because the natural number is not technically a group, we will use the word pseudo-homomorphism to
refer to a function f : N Z such that
f(m + n) = f(m) + f(n), for all m, n N
The mapping will be dened as follows
Denition 2.6.2 (Natural embedding in the integers). For each n N, the corresponding element in Z
is the equivalence class of n 0. In other words, the pseudo-homomorphism f : N Z is
f(n) = n 0, for all nN
This pseudo-homomorphism is valid for both addition and multiplication. That is
m + n = (m 0) + (n 0)
and
m n = (m 0) (n 0)
We cam verify these two equations very quickly using the operations denitions. Due to this homomorphism,
we can think of any given natural number as strictly a natural number or as in terms of its corresponding
integer. For example, we can think of the number 2 N as 2 or as 2 0, 3 1, 4 2, ... Z. It does not
matter much since all the usual operations are the same. To add two natural numbers 2 and 3 for example,
we can think of it as adding 2 and 3 in the natural which yields 5. Equivalently, we can think of the addition
as adding (2, 0) = 2 0 and (3, 0) = 3 0, which yields (5, 0) = 5 0 the integer counterpart of the
natural number 5.
Strictly speaking, N is not really a subset of Z. This is because Z is essentially the Cartesian product
N N. That is Z and N are two totally dierent types of objects: each element in N consists of a single
number while each element of Z is a 2-tuple of some elements in N. But through this pseudo-homomorphism,
N is just as good as a subset of N.

2.8 Ordering
Similar to the ordering of the naturals, we now dene some ordering relation on the integers.
Denition 2.8.1 (Positive/Negative). An integer x = a b is called positive if a > b. If a = b, then
as we dened before, x is 0. Otherwise, if a < b, then x is negative.
Theorem 7 (Sign of integers). For any given integer x, we can expect exactly one of the following case to
be true
x is positive
x is negative
x is 0
As we know from the trichotomy, given two natural numbers a and b, exactly one of the following must
be true
a > b
b > a
a = b
Thus, the trichotomy of the integers follow directly from that of the naturals.
Denition 2.8.2 (Trichotomy of integers). For x, y Z, we dene
x > y if and only if x y is positive
x = y if and only if x y = 0
We know that exactly one of the following must be true
1. x > y
38 CHAPTER 2. INTEGERS
2. x = y
3. y > x
Proof. This is quite straightforward. We dene the ordering between x and y in terms of the sign of x y.
Because of the closure of subtraction, x y is an integer. Any given integer must either be 0, positive, or
negative, leading uniquely to one ordering between x and y.

Pedro Tamaros comment Look at (0, 1). You can stretch it out innitely to the side and it will look just
look R . In fact, you can see it is similar to R since it has no visible end, i.e., you can zoom near 1 or
0 and you would keep on going indenitely, never getting to 0 or 1. However, when you look at [0, 1], you
will bump into 0 or 1, and youll see that this, in some sense, ends. From the MO thread, whenever
one takes an innite number of steps in the space, eventually one must get arbitrarily close to some other
point of the space.
Christian Blatters answer.
You may read various descriptions and consequences of compactness here. But be aware that compactness
is a very subtle niteness concept. The denitive codication of this concept is a fundamental achievement
of 20th century mathematics.
On the intuitive level, a space is a large set X where some notion of nearness or neighborhood is es-
tablished. A space X is compact, if you cannot slip away within X without being caught. To be a little
more precise: Assume that for each point x X a guard placed at x could survey a certain, maybe small,
neighborhood of x. If X is compact then you can do with nitely many (suitably chosen) guards.

Charles Matthews answer
Some heuristic remarks are helpful only to a subset of readers. (Maybe thats true of all heuristics, as a
meta-heuristic - if everyone accepts a rough explanation, its something rather more than that.)
Non-compactness is about being able to move o to innity in some way in a space. On the real line
you can do that to the left, or right: but bend the line round to ll all but one point on a circle (which is
compact) and you see the dierence having the other point near which you end up. This example of real
line versus circle is too simple, really. Another way you can go o to innity in a space is by having paths
branching out innitely (as in Konigs lemma, which supplies another kind of intuition).
Compactness is a major topological concept because the various ways you might try to trap movement
within a space to prevent escape to innity can be summed up in a single idea (for metric spaces, lets say).
The denition by open sets is cleaner, but the denition by sequences having to accumulate on themselves
(not necessarily to converge, but to have at least one convergent subsequence) is somewhat quicker to say.
If you restrict attention to spaces that are manifolds, you can think of continuous paths and whether they
have to wind back close to themselves or not.
Terry Tao has a nice explanation in the Princeton companion to maths. The articles also on his website:
http://www.math.ucla.edu/ tao/preprints/compactness.pdf
In some metric spaces like the Euclidean R
n
, compact sets are just closed and bounded. Bounded sets are
very easy to visualize but closed sets are much more subtle. The dierence between closed set like [0, 1] and
open set like (0, 1) seem to be dramatic. Refer to Pedro Tamaros comment.
Important stu Heine-Borel theorem, Cantor intersection theorem, BolzanoWeierstrass theorem, Fi-
nite intersection property.

Denition 7.1.1 (Innity as adherent point). Recall that a point p is an adherent point to the set K if

x < M then we have that is adherent to K
Note that topological structure can unify this denition with the usual -ball denition of nite adherent
point.

9.2 Piecewise constant functions
Denition 9.2.1 (Constant function). Let f : X R. We say that f is constant on X i there exists
c R such that f (x) = c.
Denition 9.2.2 (Piecewise constant function). Let I be a bounded interval [a, b] let f : I R and P be

on J.
We say that f is piecewise constant if there exists a partition P of I such that f is piecewise constant
with respect to P .
